title: B2 Vocabulary - Work & Phrasal Verbs
subject: english
description: Upper-intermediate vocabulary covering work-related terms, business collocations, and common phrasal verbs.

questions.text: Due to the economic crisis, the company had to make fifty employees _____.
questions.explanation: To be made 'redundant' means to lose your job because the employer no longer needs you, not because of your performance.

questions.text: I'm going to _____ for that marketing job I saw online.
questions.explanation: You 'apply for' a job. This is the standard collocation.

questions.text: The meeting has been _____ until next Tuesday.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'put off' means to postpone or delay. 'Call off' means to cancel.

questions.text: She decided to _____ her own business selling handmade jewelry.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'set up' means to start or establish a business.

questions.text: It is important to _____ a good impression at your interview.
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'make an impression' on someone.

questions.text: He _____ a lot of money as a corporate lawyer.
questions.explanation: You 'earn' a salary or money for work. You 'win' a prize or competition.

questions.text: We need to _____ into this problem immediately to find a solution.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'look into' means to investigate or examine a situation.

questions.text: The workers decided to go on _____ to protest low wages.
questions.explanation: To 'go on strike' means to stop working as a form of protest.

questions.text: Unfortunately, they _____ down my proposal.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'turn down' means to reject an offer or proposal.

questions.text: I can't meet you tonight; I have to work _____ to finish this report.
questions.explanation: 'Overtime' refers to time worked in addition to one's normal working hours.

questions.text: After twenty years of service, he decided to _____ and travel the world.
questions.explanation: 'Retire' means to stop working completely, usually due to age. 'Resign' means to leave a specific job.

questions.text: We are looking for a _____ candidate with at least five years of experience.
questions.explanation: 'Suitable' is the most common adjective to describe a candidate who has the right qualities for a job.

questions.text: Can you _____ with this difficult client? I don't know what to say to him.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'deal with' means to handle, take action, or solve a problem regarding a person or situation.

questions.text: My daily _____ takes about 45 minutes by train.
questions.explanation: A 'commute' is the regular journey between work and home.

questions.text: The company has a _____ for a senior accountant.
questions.explanation: A 'vacancy' is an available job or position.

questions.text: Please don't _____ up that topic again; we've already discussed it.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'bring up' means to mention or introduce a topic.

questions.text: If you work hard, you might get a _____ soon.
questions.explanation: A 'promotion' is the advancement of an employee to a higher position.

questions.text: We have a strict deadline to _____.
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'meet a deadline' when you finish work on time.

questions.text: He took _____ too much work and now he is stressed.
questions.explanation: Phrasal verb 'take on' means to accept responsibility or work.

questions.text: She has a very busy _____, with meetings all day.
questions.explanation: 'Schedule' is the most appropriate word for a plan of activities or events in a work context.
